Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, thick flakes swirling in the headlights as I inched the taxi along the icy road. My passenger kept glancing at his watch, his voice tight as he reminded me—again—that his flight to Tokyo was in less than two hours. I gripped the wheel, heart pounding, trying to focus on the slippery streets and the anxious man in the back seat. My phone buzzed in the cup holder. It was a message from Mom: “Just checking in, hope you’re safe in this weather. Love you.” I hadn’t replied to her last text, and guilt twisted in my stomach. She worried when I drove in storms, always wanting to hear from me, but I couldn’t risk taking my eyes off the road. The passenger’s sighs grew louder, the snow kept falling, and my phone buzzed again. I felt torn in two—my mother’s daughter, her only child, and a driver responsible for a stranger’s urgent journey. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I didn’t know which role to answer first.
